results.title: Kylie Tennant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Kylie Tennant drew her inspiration from people she knew, and her exuberant interview is in itself a valuable piece of Australian social history.

results.title: Douglas Stewart
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Playwright and poet, Douglas Stewart, was for many years the Literary Editor of the Bulletin, and friend of many writers and artists, including Norman Lindsay, Judith Wright and David Campbell.

results.title: The First few months
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
Parents are likely to encounter some problems during the first few months after the birth of their child. These problems include meeting the needs of demanding babies, coping with an unsettled baby, maintaining support when tired and irritable, and simply finding some peace and quiet. Relaxation techniques are discussed, ways to handle babies are demonstrated and preparations for “baby’s” first venture “outside” by car, travel, etc are also discussed.

results.title: South America: votes or violence
results.creator_credit: Anthony Isaacs, Jeremy Isaacs, Intertel and Rediffusion
results.brief_description: Examines the suitability of a democratic form of government for three Latin American countries - Bolivia, Brazil, Chile. It cannot be assumed that their political and economic problems can be solved by Western European methods. Bolivia cannot readily revive its economy based on a barren plateau of worked out mines. Brazil, with greater potential consists of ultra modern, prosperous cities and poverty stricken desert and jungle - should the government develop the profitable sections or tackle the desperate poverty? Chile with similar extremes of wealth, is experimenting with democracy. Written and narrated by James Cameron. Guitarist: John Williams. Intertel is a joint venture of Rediffusion London, Australian Broadcasting Commission, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, National Education T/V and Westinghouse Broadcasting Company of the United States.

results.title: Solomon Islands regain independence
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: On July 7, 1978, Solomon Islands regained its independence from Britain. Looks at the people of these islands and studies their way of life through their comments, songs and dances. Describes the problems facing the new nation and what is being done to combat them. Pidgin dialogue, English dialogue, English subtitles.

results.title: Steve Mcqueen Man on the Edge
results.brief_description: An acknowledged star, he was also an intensely private man. Despite accolades and huge earnings in his own mind he remained a street kid who made it. This film includes clips from his greatest films, never-before-seen home movies and interviews with directors, producers, agents, fellow actors, friends and family members.

results.title: Field Diary
results.brief_description: This film examines the Israeli occupation of the West Bank. Israeli filmmaker Amos Gitai interviews Israeli soldiers, Palestinians whose homes have been destroyed or taken from them, and new Israeli settlers.

results.title: Friends and Enemies
results.brief_description: This is a provocative film about one of the most vicious and protracted labour disputes in Australian history. In February 1985, over one thousand electrical workers went on strike against the introduction of contractors into the South East Queensland Electricity Board. Rated: PG

results.title: Snakes and ladders
results.creator_credit: Trish FitzSimons, Mitzi Goldman and Wisteria Films
results.brief_description: An experimental documentary which looks at the history of women and their education through a series of film clips, old footage, animation and interviews. Sophia Whist is a character on a journey of enquiry. She discovers an old book in the public library which comes alive. In its pages she meets ten women between the ages of 16 and 94, who talk about their education. Their stories are about wanting an education, wanting more from their education, fighting to extend their options, and demanding to be taught material that incorporates the experience of women. They reveal how women’s achievements in one generation are often hidden in the next making it difficult for women to draw on the wealth of knowledge and experience of their predecessors. Cast: Robin Laurie.
